current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text: To reauthorize and amend the National Sea Grant College Program Act, and for other purposes.

text.#text: Section 209(b) (

external-xref.#tail:
)
			 is amended by amending paragraph (2) to read as follows:

header.#text: National Sea Grant Advisory Board report

text.#text:
The Board shall report to the Congress every 3 years on the state of the national sea grant college
			 program. The Board shall indicate in each such report the progress made
			 toward meeting the priorities identified in the strategic plan in effect
			 under section 204(c). The Secretary shall make available to the Board such
			 information, personnel, and administrative services and assistance as it
			 may reasonably require to carry out its duties under this title.

Section 212(a) (

by striking
by striking the period at the end of subparagraph (F) and inserting a semicolon; and
by adding at the end the following:
$72,000,000 for fiscal year 2015;
$75,600,000 for fiscal year 2016;

$91,900,000 for fiscal year 2020.
in paragraph (2), by striking
by adding at the end the following:

header.#text: Priority activities for fiscal years 2015 through 2020

text.#text:
In addition to the amounts authorized under paragraph (1), there is authorized to be appropriated
			 for each of fiscal years 2015 through 2020 
      $18,000,000 for competitive grants for the following:
University research on the biology, prevention, and control of aquatic nonnative species.
University research on oyster diseases, oyster restoration, and oyster-related human health risks.
University research on the biology, prevention, and forecasting of harmful algal blooms.

University research, education, training, and extension services and activities focused on regional
			 or national priority issues identified in the strategic plan under section
			 204(c)(1).

Fishery extension activities conducted by sea grant colleges or sea grant institutes to enhance,
			 and not supplant, existing core program funding.
